Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Child Acquisition of Sociolinguistic Variation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Public schools in the United States are responsible for the education of more linguistically- and ethnically-diverse students than ever. A consequential part of this linguistic diversity is diversity in dialect of English spoken, as varying dialects of English characterize different socio-economic, ethnic, and racial communities and networks. Children enrolling in their first year of public schooling will exhibit the linguistic forms and patterns they have heard in input from their caregivers and the community surrounding their home environment. In many cases, the dialect learned at home may differ substantially from the variety of English used by teachers and peers. This change in input may prompt a child to alter their language, either through the development of the ability to code-switch or style-shift, or through a trade of the forms and patterns they learned from caregivers in favor of those used by their peers. A study of the mechanisms and outcomes of peer linguistic learning in a diverse peer group will add much to the understanding of first language development as well as social development at this age. This study, by focusing on a small Greater Boston metropolitan area city with an extent of ethnic, racial, linguistic, and socioeconomic diversity representative of similar metropolitan areas in the region, addresses an under-representation of multi-dialectal and multi-cultural public early education communities in the region. It seeks to not only document child linguistic, social, and sociolinguistic development, but also to provide a datapoint that will inform future American early education language learning policies and practices.

This study investigates the acquisition of new dialect forms and patterns of variable language through accommodation to peers in the Kindergarten classroom. Participants in the study (n=30), children in their first year of public schooling, have enrolled in a socioeconomically, ethnically, racially, and linguistically diverse Kindergarten class in a small industrial city in the Greater Boston metropolitan area. Linguistic diversity includes, not only the presence of languages other than English--such as Spanish and Portuguese--among peers, but also features associated with various dialects, ethnolects, and varieties of English, such as Eastern New England English, Latino English, African American English, and phenomena associated with second-language English. Participants will be audio-recorded speaking naturally and spontaneously throughout a week of classes at 10 time-points throughout the 2017-2018 school year. These recordings will be analyzed for convergence between peers across (9) relevant sociolinguistic variables. A component tracking peer physical proximity and mutual affinities will extricate automatic processes of linguistic accommodation from the role of the social factors which have been hypothesized to mediate it in previous research. If social elements such as social group and network formation are found to influence the rate, extent, or direction of accommodation among peers across any of the contexts of variation, this will be concrete evidence of the development of sociolinguistic competence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Shannon Mooney has completed research for her dissertation 'Child Acquisition of Sociolinguistic Variation' supported by the NSF Dissertation Improvement Grant. Her funding period provided her the opportunity to undertake a year of participant observation fieldwork on location at a public bilingual immersion elementary school in Framingham, Massachusetts, where she collected audio recordings at monthly timepoints from over 30 Kindergarten students. Her research undertaken at the fieldsite and based off of the audio recordings and related study materials enables a more precise understanding of the influence of exposure to multiple dialects and languages in the late stages of the early childhood language acquisition process.

 

Mooney collaborated with school administrators and teachers to understand the bilingual immersion school environment and the implications of a bilingual immersion early education environment for the acquisition of multiple dialects, registers, and styles of speaking, as well as developmental changes in attention paid to the social correlates of language variation within peer groups. The grant also enabled the hiring of research assistants local to the fieldsite who brought additional knowledge to the project as both community insiders and as specialists in early childhood education and bilingual education.

 

The data collected by Mooney enabled her to begin to offer evidence in support of the hypothesis that, even among children as young as 5-6 years old, production of variable language may be socially-meaningful -- similar to what is found with older adolescent and adult populations. She was able to show this specifically through their acquisition and variation in use of local dialect features commonly associated with the 'Boston accent' (Eastern New England English). Even among children with caregivers originally from outside of the Boston area who self-described as having accented speech from a different region, as well as among children who primarily or entirely speak a language other than English at home and elsewhere outside of school, Mooney tracked the development of local Eastern New England English dialect features over the course of the school year. 

 

She found a striking correlation between the development of local dialect features and the relationships and friendships formed between peers. This suggests that it is not necessarily any adultlike awareness of regional dialect variation, but rather a relationship to another individual and an adoption of, or accommodation to, their way of speaking that could motivate any dialect variation or change at this stage of language development. Mooney's dissertation will be defended in February 2020. Its contribution to the field of linguistics is its exploration of a large amount of natural language data from an understudied age-group that may hold the answers to key questions about the interaction between social awareness and first language development. More broadly, its innovative methodology for a large-scale study of a complex and underrepresented fieldsite -- namely, a public bilingual immersion elementary school serving a socioeconomically-diverse student population -- is hoped to encourage other researchers in linguistics and related fields to devote attention to further study of this environment.
